title: Quiz 6: Genital Disorders & Injuries
description: Test your knowledge on cysts, pelvic organ prolapse, and traumatic injuries to the genital tract.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ is the herniation of the bladder through the anterior vaginal wall, while a ___BLANK___ is the herniation of the rectum through the posterior vaginal wall.
questions.explanation: Cystocele involves the bladder (anterior); Rectocele involves the rectum (posterior).
questions.hint: Think 'Cysto' for bladder and 'Recto' for rectum.

questions.question: Match the degree of Uterine Prolapse with its description:

pairs.right: Slight descent, cervix remains in vagina
Cervix projects beyond the vulva upon straining

questions.explanation: Degrees indicate how far the uterus has descended. Third degree is complete prolapse.
questions.hint: The higher the degree, the lower the uterus.

questions.question: What is the preferred treatment for a Bartholin's abscess to preserve the gland's function?
questions.explanation: Marsupialisation allows the abscess to drain properly and preserves the function of the gland.
questions.hint: A surgical technique creating a permanent opening.

questions.question: Which muscle group is NOT part of the main pelvic floor muscles (Levator Ani)?
questions.explanation: The pelvic floor consists of iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis. Rectus abdominis is an abdominal muscle.
questions.hint: Which one is in the stomach area?

questions.question: Which of the following are preventive measures for uterine prolapse? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Prevention involves reducing trauma (episiotomy, avoiding traumatic delivery) and strengthening muscles (Kegels).
questions.hint: Think about protecting and strengthening the pelvic floor.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of Vesicovaginal Fistula (VVF) in developing countries?
questions.explanation: Obstructed labour accounts for 85% of VVF cases in developing countries due to pressure necrosis.

questions.question: A fresh Vesicovaginal Fistula (VVF) should be surgically repaired immediately upon diagnosis, regardless of tissue condition.
questions.explanation: If not noticed immediately, 2-3 months should elapse before repair to allow inflammation to settle. Fresh tears can be repaired immediately, but 'fistula' implies established necrosis.
questions.hint: Tissue needs to be healthy to hold sutures.

questions.question: Which symptom is characteristic of a Rectovaginal Fistula (RVF)?
questions.explanation: RVF involves a connection between the rectum and vagina, leading to the passage of faeces/flatus/mucus through the vagina.

questions.question: Order the steps in the postoperative care of VVF repair:

items.text: Discharge with advice for future C-section

questions.explanation: Drainage is critical for healing. Fluids flush the system. Future deliveries must be by C-section to protect the repair.
questions.hint: Drainage is the most critical factor.

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for Lichen Sclerosus (atrophic dystrophy) of the vulva?
questions.explanation: A mixture of hydrocortisone and testosterone is beneficial for lichen sclerosus.
questions.hint: It's a skin condition treated topically.
